item.title: Ukraine Goes After Moscow’s Shadow Fleet in International Waters
item.description: Recent strikes are hitting at the core of Russia’s economy, but they are risky, and their ultimate impact is uncertain.
item.dc:creator: James Marson

item.title: Oil Lower as Investors Focus on Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Oil was down in early Asian trading following a choppy session, as geopolitical tensions roiled the market, ANZ research analysts said.

item.title: China’s Services-Sector Activity Growth Slows
item.description: The RatingDog general services purchasing managers index fell to 52.1, marking the lowest level in five months, according to a statement released Wednesday.

item.title: A Newly Confident China Is Jockeying for More Global Clout as Trump Pulls Back
item.description: Feeling empowered after a clash over trade, Beijing is looking to exploit America’s inward turn.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Marathon Russia-U.S. Meeting Yields No Ukraine Peace Deal
item.description: Territory has emerged as one of the main stumbling blocks to a deal. Russia has demanded that Kyiv cede all of the eastern Ukrainian region of the Donbas.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: ‘Welcome to America!’ Captured Drug Lords Choose: Snitch or Suffer
item.description: Under pressure from the Trump administration, Mexico turned over 55 cartel leaders in a pair of cloak-and-dagger missions.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Opinion | Trump Strikes a Good Drug Deal
item.description: In return for no U.S. pharma tariffs, the U.K. will ease price controls.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Britain’s Big Welfare Con Job
item.description: Rule No. 1: Don’t lie to voters about social spending and taxes.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | No Fire Critics Allowed in Hong Kong
item.description: Authorities move to silence dissent after the blaze that killed 151.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Notable & Quotable: Lost in Woke Translation
item.description: ‘Then a black Dutch fashion blogger wrote an article saying that Gorman’s work should only be translated by a black woman.’

item.title: Pope Leo Urges the U.S. Not to Threaten Venezuela With Force
item.description: The pontiff calls on the Trump administration to push for change in Venezuela through peaceful means.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Walker

item.title: Opinion | A Speck of Sawdust in Kyiv
item.description: Corruption is a problem in Ukraine. But have you seen Illinois?

item.title: Former Honduran President Walks Out of Prison After Trump Pardon
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández, serving a 45-year sentence for drug trafficking, is released as Honduras faces a nearly tied presidential election.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: In Nigeria, Target of a Trump Threat, Parents Fear for Kidnapped Children
item.description: Fed up with Nigeria’s inability to stop mass abductions of students, families ask the U.S. for assistance.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Reproached by Trump, Netanyahu Is Open to a Syria-Israel Deal—With Caveats
item.description: The Israeli leader demands a large buffer zone after Trump warned Israel against actions that could destabilize the new government in Damascus.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: Opinion | Shooting the Wounded on Drug Boats?
item.description: Congress is right to seek the truth about the alleged Hegseth missile order.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: TotalEnergies Says Mozambique LNG Partners Will Cover Cash Shortfall After U.K., Dutch Pullout
item.description: British and Dutch authorities dropped out following repeated media reports of alleged human-rights abuses by security forces of the southern African nation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Loosens Bank Capital Demands for First Time Since Financial Crisis
item.description: British banks will no longer need to hold so much capital, as the U.K. joins the U.S. in unwinding some measures put in place after the global financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: Joe Wallace

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Picks Up as Services Prices Accelerate
item.description: The inflation rate in the eurozone rose further in November above the European Central Bank’s target, making a cut in the key interest rate less likely.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Chinese Rare-Earth Dealers Find Ways to Dodge Beijing’s Export Restrictions
item.description: Companies are tweaking magnet formulas and embedding them in motors to keep selling to the West.
item.dc:creator: Jon Emont

item.title: Europe’s Green Energy Rush Slashed Emissions—and Crippled the Economy
item.description: The aggressive push to cut fossil fuels brought an unwelcome twist: dramatically higher electricity costs that are hobbling industry.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: He Was Convicted of Running a Narco State. Now Trump Plans to Pardon Him.
item.description: Former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernández was sentenced to 45 years in prison for receiving millions of dollars for protecting drug smugglers.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: Trump’s Push to End the Ukraine War Is Sowing Fresh Fear About NATO’s Future
item.description: The U.S.’s latest efforts to end the conflict between Ukraine and Russia have jolted the trans-Atlantic alliance.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: Hong Kong’s Response to Deadly Fire Is Squeezed by China’s Firm Hand
item.description: Official efforts to control the public response include a threat to arrest those who direct their anger at the government.
item.dc:creator: Jason Chau

item.title: Algoma Steel to Cut 1,000 Workers Due to Tariffs
item.description: The Canadian steel maker said it would eliminate about a third of its workforce, as the company shuts down production from its blast furnace and coke ovens that became financially unsustainable with hefty U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: U.K. Budget Watchdog Head Quits After Early Report Release
item.description: The head of the U.K.’s budget watchdog resigned after a review found the organization had failed to protect its market-sensitive assessment of government measures from premature access.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sudan Offers Russia Its First Naval Base in Africa
item.description: A Red Sea port would give Moscow a vital edge in strategically critical waters.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Pope Leo Visits a Dwindling Christian Flock in the Middle East
item.description: The pope is seeking to make communities feel less isolated and to encourage them to remain in their ancestral lands.
item.dc:creator: Omar Abdel-Baqui

item.title: Conservative Candidate Backed by Trump Has Narrow Lead in Honduran Election
item.description: Nasry “Tito” Asfura got a boost after President Trump’s endorsement upended a tight race.
item.dc:creator: Juan Carlos Rivera

item.title: How Venezuelan Gangs and African Jihadists Are Flooding Europe With Cocaine
item.description: Surging trans-Atlantic drug flows mean that cocaine seizures in Europe now exceed those in North America.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: China Private Gauge Signals Weaker Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Growth in China’s manufacturing production came to a halt as new orders nearly stalled last month despite a renewed rise in new orders from abroad.

item.title: After ‘Productive’ Meeting With Ukrainian Negotiators in Florida, U.S. Officials Head to Russia
item.description: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner plan to travel to Moscow for more talks about a possible peace plan.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Netanyahu Asks for a Pardon After Trump Says He Should Get One
item.description: Israel’s prime minister, who was indicted on bribery and other charges in 2019, has officially requested a pardon as his trial continues.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: Scotland Wants to Issue Its Own Bonds. Last Time It Paid With Its Independence.
item.description: The first Scottish bonds in over 300 years, already known as “kilts,” could help exorcise the ghosts of the past.
item.dc:creator: James Hookway

item.title: Now Poorer Countries Are Shutting the Door on Refugees Too
item.description: Uganda had been a notable exception to a worldwide pull-up-the-drawbridge trend—until now.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: In Miami’s ‘Little Venezuela,’ Deportation Fears Collide With Hope for Regime Change
item.description: Residents of the largest Venezuelan community in the U.S. are caught between Trump’s immigration crackdown and his campaign against Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Vera Bergengruen

item.title: China Manufacturing Gauge Shows Slightly Firmer Growth Momentum
item.description: China’s official factory gauge edged up on stronger production and demand in November, but remained in contraction for an eighth straight month.

item.title: China Used to Be a Cash Cow for Western Companies. Now It’s a Test Lab.
item.description: Competition has pushed some brands to adapt to Chinese tastes and introduce lower prices—and use the country as an innovation hub.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: Russia Gains the Upper Hand in the Drone Battle, Once Ukraine’s Forte
item.description: The growing ability of Russia’s troops to hit Ukrainian supply lines with drones is seen as a more significant shift than its incremental gains in territory.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Walker

item.title: My Three Weeks Navigating Ice in the Arctic Ocean
item.description: In a paradox of global warming, thawing ice isn’t making Arctic waters easier to navigate. It makes them more dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Kiss

item.title: Why Russia and China Are Sitting Out Venezuela’s Clash With Trump
item.description: The ‘Axis of Authoritarianism’ is depleted by the war in Ukraine and preoccupied with trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: James T. Areddy

item.title: Make Money Not War: Trump’s Real Plan for Peace in Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin pitched the White House on peace through business. To Europe’s dismay, the president and his envoy are on board.
item.dc:creator: Annie Ng

item.title: Mystery Blasts Rock Russia-Linked Oil Tankers Off Turkey’s Coast
item.description: The two vessels belong to the so-called shadow fleet that Moscow has tapped to sidestep Western sanctions on the movement of its oil.
item.dc:creator: Elvan Kivilcim

item.title: New Peace Push Offers Clues to Fundamental Question: What Does Putin Want?
item.description: The Russian leader wants far more than just the conquest of eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: Zelensky’s Top Aide Resigns as Corruption Probe Deepens
item.description: The departure of Ukraine’s top negotiator—the president’s right-hand man Andriy Yermak—comes at a pivotal moment for the country.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: Deadly Clash Deepens Rift Between Israel and Syria
item.description: Israel’s military says its troops entered an area in southern Syria to apprehend two suspected militants when they came under fire.
item.dc:creator: Feliz Solomon

item.title: ‘There Was No Alarm’: Hong Kong Inferno Spread Across Towers in Silence
item.description: Shrouded buildings and broken alarms left many apartment dwellers unaware of the unfolding disaster.
item.dc:creator: Yang Jie

item.title: Nexperia Urges China Unit to Restore Chip Flow Amid Fears of Supply Squeeze
item.description: The Chinese owner of Nexperia, Wingtech Technology, in response called on its Dutch subsidiary to enter talks over control of the company.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The Deadly Mix of Factors That Made a Hong Kong High-Rise Fire So Devastating
item.description: A blaze in a densely packed housing complex took more than 24 hours to bring under control and was the deadliest in decades.
item.dc:creator: Jason Chau

item.title: Trump Is Silent on Taiwan After Talking to Xi—and That Is Fine With Taipei
item.description: Taiwan is making the most of the U.S.’s policy of “strategic ambiguity,” even as President Trump’s stance raises concern for some.
item.dc:creator: Joyu Wang

item.title: Officials Clashed in Investigation of Deadly Air India Crash
item.description: Tension and suspicion between U.S. and Indian experts have marked the continuing inquiry into the crash of a Boeing 787 Dreamliner.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Tangel

item.title: ‘Deliver or Die’: Inside the Drug-Boat Crews Ferrying Cocaine to the U.S.
item.description: The high-seas cowboys who speed tons of cocaine to American consumers are now getting blown out of the water. They say it won’t stop them.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Putin Says U.S. Plan for Ending Ukraine War a Starting Point, Needs Work
item.description: In his first public comments about the latest U.S. push for peace between Russia and Ukraine, the Russian leader described the plan as a list of questions requiring work.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: U.K. Budget Trims Inflation But Offers Limited Relief for BOE
item.description: The budget is unlikely to cool inflation in a sustained manner that would open the way for many more rate cuts, economists say.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Germany’s Secret Plan for War With Russia
item.description: A classified blueprint shows why weapons or troop numbers alone may not decide the outcome of a broader conflict between Moscow and the West.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: Leaked U.S.-Russia Call Sets Off Global Game of Clue: Who Did It—And Why?
item.description: Diplomats and amateur sleuths are chasing questions of means and motive, including who had the capacity to eavesdrop on a call between top officials and who would benefit the most from leaking the conversation?
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: U.K. Unveils Sweeping New Tax Hikes
item.description: The Treasury chief said the measures, from a tax on more expensive properties to a levy on sweet dairy products such as milkshakes, would patch up public finances.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: School Kidnappings Have Become a Cruel Fact of Life in Nigeria
item.description: President Trump has threatened military intervention to head off what he says is the persecution of Christians, but children of all faiths are abducted, often for money.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Militants Abduct 300 Children From Catholic School in Nigeria
item.description: Students were taken from their dormitories and forced into the forest at gunpoint, police said.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Storied South African Club Embodies Decline of Former Gold Capital
item.description: Founded by white mining magnates, the Rand Club mirrors South Africa’s rise and fall as the capital of the global gold industry.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Pakistan Points Finger at India Over Suicide Blast
item.description: The accusation came as India’s prime minister vowed to find the perpetrators of a separate deadly explosion on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Krishna Pokharel

item.title: Car Explosion in India’s Capital Kills Eight
item.description: Indian officials said it was too early to say if the blast was the result of a bomb.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Will India and China Be Able to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Russian Oil?
item.description: New Delhi and Beijing have so far resisted U.S. calls to stop buying Russian crude, but far-reaching sanctions will be hard to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Jiahui Huang

item.title: Trump Signals Support for Selling Submarines to Australia
item.description: The president’s comments calmed fears that he would pull out of the Biden-era deal and came as he struck an agreement with the U.S. ally on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: How a Right-Wing Hindu Group Went From Fringe to Mainstream in India
item.description: India’s Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh group is stepping out of the shadows and flexing its power.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Trump Organization Expands in India, Where Many of Its Partners Face Accusations
item.description: Indian real-estate firms have been accused of fraud, money laundering and more on other projects. The Trumps have stepped up overseas deals in the president’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grant

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Selinger

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.
item.dc:creator: Sal Vaglica

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.
item.dc:creator: Sarah E. Needleman

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
